content.verbatim_text: When planning acquisitions or such other corporate transactions, the acquiring party will usually have to consider how it prefers to structure the transactions. The acquiring party can either elect to purchase the target company's assets (which enables the acquiring party to pick and choose only the assets and contracts they desire) or alternatively it may elect to acquire the entire company. In an asset sale, the need for contract-by-contract due diligence, would become particularly important since each contract needs to be specifically assigned in the context of asset sale. The acquiring party would generally be able to avoid such issues by electing to acquire the entire share capital of the target company (thereby making it a subsidiary of the acquiring entity) or by merging together with the target company. In the latter case (i.e. when the acquiring party obtains all outstanding shares in the target company and makes the acquired company its subsidiary), there is strictly speaking no need to obtain a consent for the assignment of the related contracts. This is because the contracts in themselves are not ‘assigned’ to any new legal entity but only the owner of the existing legal entity changes. Contrary to widely held belief, changes in ownership do not generally require the other contracting party’s consent. In companies whose shares are stock-listed the ownership changes each day the market is open. An acquisition or a merger would in most countries serve to "vest" all assets and liabilities including contracts automatically to a merging and surviving entity or the acquiring party, as the case may be, by ‘operation of law’ without a need to obtain a consent from the opposing party.
content.plain_text: When structuring acquisitions, parties choose between asset purchase (requiring contract-by-contract assignment and due diligence) or share purchase/merger. In a share purchase or merger, contracts are generally transferred by 'operation of law' without requiring consent from the other contracting party, as the legal entity remains the same or vests automatically. This is contrary to a common misconception.
content.expert_insight: This provides crucial background on the legal distinction between asset sales and share sales/mergers regarding contract transfer. Understanding 'operation of law' is key to avoiding unnecessary consent requirements and streamlining M&A processes.
content.justification: Explains the legal mechanisms and implications of different M&A structures on contract assignment, particularly the concept of 'assignment by operation of law'.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can strategically structure acquisitions (e.g., via share purchase or merger) to bypass individual contract assignment consent requirements, simplifying and accelerating transactions.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware that their contracts may transfer automatically in certain M&A scenarios (share purchase/merger) without their explicit consent, unless specific change of control clauses exist.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly addresses a 'widely held belief' that changes in ownership require consent, clarifying the legal reality of 'operation of law'.
content.text: When planning acquisitions or such other corporate transactions, the acquiring party will usually have to consider how it prefers to structure the transactions. The acquiring party can either elect to purchase the target company's assets (which enables the acquiring party to pick and choose only the assets and contracts they desire) or alternatively it may elect to acquire the entire company. In an asset sale, the need for contract-by-contract due diligence, would become particularly important since each contract needs to be specifically assigned in the context of asset sale. The acquiring party would generally be able to avoid such issues by electing to acquire the entire share capital of the target company (thereby making it a subsidiary of the acquiring entity) or by merging together with the target company. In the latter case (i.e. when the acquiring party obtains all outstanding shares in the target company and makes the acquired company its subsidiary), there is strictly speaking no need to obtain a consent for the assignment of the related contracts. This is because the contracts in themselves are not ‘assigned’ to any new legal entity but only the owner of the existing legal entity changes. Contrary to widely held belief, changes in ownership do not generally require the other contracting party’s consent. In companies whose shares are stock-listed the ownership changes each day the market is open. An acquisition or a merger would in most countries serve to "vest" all assets and liabilities including contracts automatically to a merging and surviving entity or the acquiring party, as the case may be, by ‘operation of law’ without a need to obtain a consent from the opposing party.

content.verbatim_text: The parties are of course free to agree between themselves that a ownership change of certain magnitude (in e.g. affecting over 50 % of all outstanding shares) will require the other party’s consent. Also, clauses that prohibit any transfer by any kind of merger or "change of control" are not uncommon. Below is an example of such clause: “Any attempted assignment of this [Agreement] whether directly, by change in control or by operation of law, shall be ineffective unless effected with the other party’s prior written consent”. Variants of the above provision can be found in particular in suppliers’ own contract templates.
content.plain_text: Parties can contractually agree that a change of ownership (e.g., over 50% shares) or a change of control will require consent, overriding the 'operation of law' principle. Such clauses, like the provided example, are common, especially in supplier templates.
content.expert_insight: This highlights a contractual override to the default 'operation of law' rule. Zebracorp must be vigilant for these 'change of control' clauses, as they can reintroduce the very consent requirements that share purchases aim to avoid.
content.justification: Explains how contractual clauses can modify the default legal position regarding assignment by operation of law, and provides an example.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must carefully review contracts for 'change of control' clauses that could negate the benefits of assignment by operation of law during M&A.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can use 'change of control' clauses to retain control over who they contract with, even in share purchase scenarios, potentially gaining leverage.
content.source_insight: The example clause directly illustrates the type of language Zebracorp needs to watch out for.
content.text: The parties are of course free to agree between themselves that a ownership change of certain magnitude (in e.g. affecting over 50 % of all outstanding shares) will require the other party’s consent. Also, clauses that prohibit any transfer by any kind of merger or "change of control" are not uncommon. Below is an example of such clause: “Any attempted assignment of this [Agreement] whether directly, by change in control or by operation of law, shall be ineffective unless effected with the other party’s prior written consent”. Variants of the above provision can be found in particular in suppliers’ own contract templates.

content.verbatim_text: While we may want to restrict the supplier from changing ownership or control without our approval, Zebracorp is often not itself willing to agree to such restrictions. Zebracorp’s firm view is that assignment of contract by operation of law should not require the supplier’s consent, and in most cases we should reject any language that requires us to seek consent from other party in connection with transfer of agreement by operation of law. This is largely due to the fact that these type of provisions are likely to cause complications when planning mergers, acquisitions or such other transactions. For example, if Zebracorp was planning on forming a merger with another company, we would work from the assumption that our contracts with our suppliers/subcontractors would be automatically transferred to the new merged entity by operation of law without the need seek consents from our supplier base. An assignment restriction described above is likely to impact the timing, cost and our ability to consummate a "smooth" merger or such other transaction.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's firm stance is to reject clauses requiring consent for assignment by operation of law, even if it imposes similar restrictions on suppliers. Such clauses complicate M&A, impacting timing, cost, and deal smoothness. Zebracorp assumes its contracts will automatically transfer in a merger.
content.expert_insight: This outlines Zebracorp's aggressive negotiation position against 'change of control' clauses that would require consent for transfers by operation of law. It highlights the practical M&A complications these clauses create for Zebracorp.
content.justification: This is a clear statement of Zebracorp's negotiation policy and the strategic rationale behind it, including an illustrative example.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp aims to preserve its M&A flexibility, avoiding delays and costs associated with seeking numerous consents during corporate transactions.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will face resistance if they attempt to include 'change of control' clauses that require consent for Zebracorp's transfers by operation of law.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly states 'Zebracorp’s firm view' and provides a 'For example' scenario to illustrate the impact.

An assignment restriction described above is likely to impact the timing, cost and our ability to consummate a "smooth" merger or such other transaction.

content.verbatim_text: In those critical R&D contracts and the like where we do impose these very same assignment restrictions on our suppliers, it would be better to abandon the entire clause than to agree to mutual clause that would restrict Zebracorp from assigning the contract. The fact that Zebracorp is not willing to make these assignment provisions mutual can often be explained to the supplier by the asymmetric contractual relationship i.e. that of the customer and the supplier. In most cases, we can make the contract more palatable to the supplier by agreeing to allow the supplier transfer the contract by operation of law to any party that is not a direct competitor of Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: For critical R&D contracts where Zebracorp restricts supplier assignment, it's better to remove the clause entirely than to make it mutual and restrict Zebracorp. This asymmetry can be justified by the customer-supplier relationship. To make it more acceptable, Zebracorp can allow suppliers to transfer by operation of law to non-competitors.
content.expert_insight: This provides a nuanced negotiation strategy for high-stakes contracts. Zebracorp prioritizes its own flexibility over restricting suppliers, even if it means sacrificing some control. It also offers a compromise to make the non-mutual stance more palatable to suppliers.
content.justification: This outlines a specific negotiation strategy for critical contracts where Zebracorp's own flexibility is paramount, including a justification and a potential compromise.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp maintains its strategic flexibility in M&A, even in critical R&D contracts, by avoiding mutual restrictions. It also provides a way to soften the impact on suppliers.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers might gain some flexibility to transfer contracts by operation of law (to non-competitors) but will still face restrictions on direct assignment, especially in critical R&D contracts.
content.source_insight: The text offers both a 'better to abandon' strategy and a 'can often be explained' justification, along with a 'make the contract more palatable' compromise.
content.text: In those critical R&D contracts and the like where we do impose these very same assignment restrictions on our suppliers, it would be better to abandon the entire clause than to agree to mutual clause that would restrict Zebracorp from assigning the contract. The fact that Zebracorp is not willing to make these assignment provisions mutual can often be explained to the supplier by the asymmetric contractual relationship i.e. that of the customer and the supplier. content.verbatim_text: Under UK laws, an assignment of rights under a contract is normally restricted solely to the benefits of the contract. Where a party wishes to transfer both the benefit and burden of the contract without any residual liability (as is usually the case), the assignment of the contract would generally needs to be done by way of a novation. For this reason, when the agreement is governed by UK laws, it is useful to specifically mention that the agreement is not only assigned but also novated, and the transfer of the rights and obligations may require the execution of a specific novation agreement. Please speak to a member of the Legal & Compliance team to obtain the appropriate templates/language. Due to the prevalence of UK origin contract documentation, the term novation and novation agreements in general are often (incorrectly) used in other jurisdictions as well when the parties should be talking about contract transfer or assignment. This in itself is not issue in the majority of cases, as most jurisdictions will recognize the term novation to mean the same as transfer of a contract.
content.plain_text: Under UK law, assignment typically only transfers benefits. To transfer both benefits and burdens without residual liability, novation is required. For UK-governed agreements, explicitly state both assignment and novation, potentially requiring a separate novation agreement. Consult Legal & Compliance for templates. While 'novation' is often incorrectly used outside the UK, most jurisdictions understand it to mean contract transfer.
content.expert_insight: This is crucial legal nuance for contracts governed by UK law, ensuring a complete transfer of obligations and liabilities. It also provides practical advice on terminology and internal consultation.
content.justification: Provides specific legal information regarding UK contract law on assignment vs. novation, and practical instructions for handling it.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure proper legal mechanisms (novation) are used for UK-governed contracts to achieve a clean transfer of both rights and obligations, avoiding residual liability.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers in UK-governed contracts will be subject to novation requirements for full contract transfer, ensuring clarity on who holds the obligations.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly states 'Please speak to a member of the Legal & Compliance team', indicating an internal process instruction.

For this reason, when the agreement is governed by UK laws, it is useful to specifically mention that the agreement is not only assigned but also novated, and the transfer of the rights and obligations may require the execution of a specific novation agreement. Due to the prevalence of UK origin contract documentation, the term novation and novation agreements in general are often (incorrectly) used in other jurisdictions as well when the parties should be talking about contract transfer or assignment. This in itself is not issue in the majority of cases, as most jurisdictions will recognize the term novation to mean the same as transfer of a contract.

content.verbatim_text: Companies have the freedom to change the trade name that they use to conduct their business. When changing the name of the company, the registered legal entity which can be identified through each company’s individual registration number remains the same. These type of changes in the name or registered addresses of a company are not regarded as assignments so long as the underlying legal entity remains the same and only the name/address of the company changes. Accordingly, there is no need to seek or grant consent to such change of name/registered address alone. A unilateral notification of the name change to the other contracting party should be sufficient. While it is recommended to clarify the name change in future contract amendments, strictly speaking this is not necessary. The name change can be mentioned in a contract amendment in e.g. by adding a following note in brackets after the name of the contracting party: e.g. “(formerly known as Zebracorp Space)” or, in short, “(f/k/a Zebracorp Space)”
content.plain_text: Changes to a company's trade name or registered address are not considered assignments if the underlying legal entity (identified by registration number) remains the same. Therefore, no consent is needed; a unilateral notification is sufficient. While clarifying in future amendments is recommended, it's not strictly necessary, and can be done with a 'formerly known as' note.
content.expert_insight: This clarifies a common point of confusion, distinguishing between a legal entity change (assignment) and a mere name/address change. It provides practical, low-friction guidance for handling such administrative updates.
content.justification: Provides clarifying information on company name changes and their distinction from assignments, along with practical instructions for handling them.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can change its name or address without needing to seek consent from all contracting parties, simplifying administrative processes.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should understand that Zebracorp's name or address changes do not constitute an assignment requiring their consent, and a simple notification is sufficient.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly states 'there is no need to seek or grant consent' and provides an 'e.g.' for how to note the change.

content.verbatim_text: Assignment clauses can become critical in a sale of business, acquisition or other similar transaction. Having an obligation to obtain consents for assigning contracts from present contract parties can complicate and potentially sidetrack the contemplated transaction. Failure to pay close attention to the language of the assignment clause while the contract is being negotiated may also create an opportunity for the nontransferring party to later extort concessions in return to its consent to the contract assignment.
content.plain_text: Assignment clauses are vital during business sales or acquisitions. Requiring consent from contract parties for assignments can complicate or derail transactions. Neglecting assignment clause language during negotiation can lead to the non-transferring party leveraging consent for concessions.
content.expert_insight: This highlights the strategic importance of assignment clauses, particularly in M&A contexts. Proactive negotiation to secure favorable assignment terms can prevent significant delays, costs, and potential blackmail during future corporate transactions.
content.justification: Provides context on the importance and potential pitfalls of assignment clauses.
content.implication_company: Poorly negotiated assignment clauses can complicate or sidetrack future M&A activities, leading to increased costs or failed transactions. The company might be extorted for concessions.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers might gain leverage if the company needs their consent for an assignment, potentially allowing them to demand concessions.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly states the criticality and potential complications.

content.verbatim_text: It is for these reasons important to make sure that each contract we conclude gives us the maximum flexibility to assign without the supplier’s consent to any succeeding entity to Zebracorp (in case of a reorganization), or at the minimum allow free assignment by Zebracorp to an affiliate (which accomplishes the same ability for re-organization if Zebracorp is acquired through a share purchase at the shareholder level).
content.plain_text: Zebracorp must ensure contracts allow maximum flexibility for assignment without supplier consent to any successor entity during reorganization, or at least permit free assignment to an affiliate.
content.expert_insight: This is a key strategic objective for Zebracorp. Ensuring assignment flexibility is critical for business continuity and M&A activities, minimizing friction and costs. Negotiating for assignment without consent to affiliates or successors is a standard best practice for large organizations.
content.conditions: When concluding any contract.
content.justification: To avoid complications, sidetracking, and potential extortion during future reorganizations, acquisitions, or similar transactions.
content.implication_company: Achieves operational flexibility, streamlines M&A processes, and reduces potential costs and delays associated with obtaining third-party consents.

Contract splitting ensures continuity for both the divesting entity and the acquirer, which is crucial for maintaining business operations without needing to renegotiate or duplicate contracts.

content.verbatim_text: Please note that, when negotiating the assignment clause with our suppliers/subcontractors, we would not wish to agree to a mutual assignment right. This means that in most cases we would rather forego our right to assign than to agree on any language that would allow the supplier/subcontractor to freely assign the agreement to a third party without our consent.

content.expert_insight: This is a critical, non-negotiable stance for Zebracorp. The rationale is sound: Zebracorp vets its suppliers carefully, and allowing them to unilaterally substitute themselves undermines this process and poses significant risk to service quality and financial stability. This asymmetry is a common position for a customer in a supplier relationship.

Allowing free assignment by suppliers would negate this process and could lead to critical contractual commitments being unmet.

The assignment should be unconditional in the sense that Zebracorp will not accept liability for any commitments made by any third party assignee. The assignment should also provide a clean exit for Zebracorp in the sense that Zebracorp will not remain jointly liable under the assigned agreement with the new contracting party.

Remaining jointly liable negates much of the benefit of assignment, as Zebracorp would still bear the risk of the assignee's non-performance. This should be a non-negotiable point.

content.verbatim_text: When planning acquisitions or such other corporate transactions, the acquiring party will usually have to consider how it prefers to structure the transactions. The acquiring party can either elect to purchase the target company's assets (which enables the acquiring party to pick and choose only the assets and contracts they desire) or alternatively it may elect to acquire the entire company. In an asset sale, the need for contract-by-contract due diligence, would become particularly important since each contract needs to be specifically assigned in the context of asset sale. The acquiring party would generally be able to avoid such issues by electing to acquire the entire share capital of the target company (thereby making it a subsidiary of the acquiring entity) or by merging together with the target company.
content.plain_text: During corporate transactions like acquisitions, the acquiring party must decide on the transaction structure: either purchasing specific assets (requiring individual contract assignments and due diligence) or acquiring the entire target company (e.g., via share purchase or merger) to avoid individual contract assignments.
content.expert_insight: This provides essential background on M&A structuring and its implications for contract assignment. It explains why a share purchase or merger is often preferred to an asset sale when aiming to avoid complex contract-by-contract assignment processes.
content.justification: Provides context on different acquisition structures and their impact on contract assignment.
content.implication_company: Informs strategic decisions regarding M&A structure to minimize assignment-related complexities.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may experience different impacts on their contracts depending on whether their counterparty undergoes an asset sale or a share acquisition/merger.
content.source_insight: The text explains the considerations for structuring acquisitions.
content.text: When planning acquisitions or such other corporate transactions, the acquiring party will usually have to consider how it prefers to structure the transactions. The acquiring party can either elect to purchase the target company's assets (which enables the acquiring party to pick and choose only the assets and contracts they desire) or alternatively it may elect to acquire the entire company. In an asset sale, the need for contract-by-contract due diligence, would become particularly important since each contract needs to be specifically assigned in the context of asset sale. The acquiring party would generally be able to avoid such issues by electing to acquire the entire share capital of the target company (thereby making it a subsidiary of the acquiring entity) or by merging together with the target company.

content.verbatim_text: In the latter case (i.e. when the acquiring party obtains all outstanding shares in the target company and makes the acquired company its subsidiary), there is strictly speaking no need to obtain a consent for the assignment of the related contracts. This is because the contracts in themselves are not ‘assigned’ to any new legal entity but only the owner of the existing legal entity changes. Contrary to widely held belief, changes in ownership do not generally require the other contracting party’s consent. In companies whose shares are stock-listed the ownership changes each day the market is open.
content.plain_text: When an acquiring party buys all shares of a target company, making it a subsidiary, consent for contract assignment is generally not needed. This is because the contracts remain with the same legal entity; only its ownership changes. Changes in ownership typically do not require consent, as seen daily in publicly traded companies.
content.expert_insight: This clarifies a common misconception regarding 'change of control' versus 'assignment'. It's critical for M&A planning to understand that a change in the ownership of a contracting entity (e.g., through a share sale) does not, by default, constitute an assignment requiring consent, unless the contract specifically states otherwise.
content.justification: Explains why share acquisitions generally do not trigger assignment consent requirements.
content.implication_company: Provides a strategic advantage in M&A by simplifying the transfer of contracts when acquiring a company through share purchase.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers' contracts generally remain with the same legal entity, even if ownership changes, meaning they typically cannot object based on a change of control alone.
content.source_insight: The text explains the legal implications of share acquisitions regarding contract assignment.
content.text: In the latter case (i.e. when the acquiring party obtains all outstanding shares in the target company and makes the acquired company its subsidiary), there is strictly speaking no need to obtain a consent for the assignment of the related contracts. This is because the contracts in themselves are not ‘assigned’ to any new legal entity but only the owner of the existing legal entity changes. Contrary to widely held belief, changes in ownership do not generally require the other contracting party’s consent. In companies whose shares are stock-listed the ownership changes each day the market is open.

content.verbatim_text: An acquisition or a merger would in most countries serve to "vest" all assets and liabilities including contracts automatically to a merging and surviving entity or the acquiring party, as the case may be, by ‘operation of law’ without a need to obtain a consent from the opposing party.
content.plain_text: In most countries, acquisitions or mergers automatically transfer all assets, liabilities, and contracts to the surviving or acquiring entity by 'operation of law,' without requiring consent from the other contracting party.
content.expert_insight: This highlights the legal principle of 'operation of law' which can bypass consent requirements in mergers and certain acquisitions. It's a powerful mechanism for seamless transitions but can be overridden by specific contractual clauses.
content.justification: Provides information on how assets and contracts are transferred in M&A by operation of law.
content.implication_company: Simplifies asset and contract transfer during mergers and acquisitions, reducing administrative burden and potential for obstruction.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers' contracts may be automatically transferred to a new entity without their consent in the event of a merger or acquisition of their counterparty.
content.source_insight: The text describes the effect of M&A by operation of law.
content.text: An acquisition or a merger would in most countries serve to "vest" all assets and liabilities including contracts automatically to a merging and surviving entity or the acquiring party, as the case may be, by ‘operation of law’ without a need to obtain a consent from the opposing party.

content.verbatim_text: The parties are of course free to agree between themselves that a ownership change of certain magnitude (in e.g. affecting over 50 % of all outstanding shares) will require the other party’s consent.
content.plain_text: Parties can contractually agree that an ownership change of a specific magnitude (e.g., over 50% of shares) will require the other party's consent.
content.expert_insight: While 'operation of law' generally bypasses consent for ownership changes, parties can contractually override this default. This is where 'change of control' clauses come into play, which are often heavily negotiated.
content.conditions: When drafting or negotiating contracts.
content.justification: Parties have contractual freedom to define conditions for consent, even for changes that might otherwise occur by operation of law.

content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can gain control over changes in ownership of their counterparty if such a clause is included in the contract.

content.expert_insight: This is a common and highly restrictive 'change of control' clause. It explicitly overrides the default 'operation of law' principle, making it a critical point of negotiation for any company contemplating M&A.
content.justification: Provides a concrete example of a restrictive assignment/change of control clause.
content.implication_company: Illustrates a clause that Zebracorp would likely want to avoid or heavily modify in its contracts.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers might include such clauses in their templates to protect their interests against changes in their customer's ownership or legal structure.

content.verbatim_text: This is largely due to the fact that these type of provisions are likely to cause complications when planning mergers, acquisitions or such other transactions. For example, if Zebracorp was planning on forming a merger with another company, we would work from the assumption that our contracts with our suppliers/subcontractors would be automatically transferred to the new merged entity by operation of law without the need seek consents from our supplier base. An assignment restriction described above is likely to impact the timing, cost and our ability to consummate a "smooth" merger or such other transaction.

Zebracorp assumes contracts transfer automatically by operation of law in a merger.

content.verbatim_text: In those critical R&D contracts and the like where we do impose these very same assignment restrictions on our suppliers, it would be better to abandon the entire clause than to agree to mutual clause that would restrict Zebracorp from assigning the contract.

content.verbatim_text: Under UK laws, an assignment of rights under a contract is normally restricted solely to the benefits of the contract. Where a party wishes to transfer both the benefit and burden of the contract without any residual liability (as is usually the case), the assignment of the contract would generally needs to be done by way of a novation. For this reason, when the agreement is governed by UK laws, it is useful to specifically mention that the agreement is not only assigned but also novated, and the transfer of the rights and obligations may require the execution of a specific novation agreement.
content.plain_text: Under UK law, assignment typically only transfers contractual benefits. To transfer both benefits and burdens without residual liability, a novation is generally required. Therefore, for UK-governed agreements, it's advisable to specify both assignment and novation, potentially requiring a separate novation agreement.
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial distinction, particularly for contracts governed by UK law. Understanding the difference between assignment (benefits only) and novation (benefits and burdens, with release of original party) is vital to ensure the desired legal effect of a transfer.
content.justification: Explains the legal distinction between assignment and novation under UK law and its practical implications.
content.implication_company: Ensures proper legal transfer of contracts under UK law, avoiding residual liabilities or incomplete transfers.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will be subject to these specific UK legal requirements when dealing with contracts governed by UK law.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly details the UK legal context for assignment vs. novation.

For this reason, when the agreement is governed by UK laws, it is useful to specifically mention that the agreement is not only assigned but also novated, and the transfer of the rights and obligations may require the execution of a specific novation agreement.

Explicitly addressing novation ensures that both the benefits and burdens are transferred and that the original party is released from liability, which is often the desired outcome of a full contract transfer.

content.verbatim_text: Due to the prevalence of UK origin contract documentation, the term novation and novation agreements in general are often (incorrectly) used in other jurisdictions as well when the parties should be talking about contract transfer or assignment. This in itself is not issue in the majority of cases, as most jurisdictions will recognize the term novation to mean the same as transfer of a contract.
content.plain_text: The term 'novation' is often incorrectly used in non-UK jurisdictions (where 'contract transfer' or 'assignment' would be more accurate) due to the influence of UK contract documentation. However, in most cases, this is not an issue as many jurisdictions interpret 'novation' to mean a general contract transfer.
content.expert_insight: This clarifies a common linguistic and legal nuance. While precision is always best, it provides reassurance that the common misuse of 'novation' outside the UK often doesn't lead to adverse legal outcomes due to common interpretation.
content.justification: Provides context on the common (mis)use of 'novation' in different jurisdictions.
content.implication_company: Informs on potential linguistic discrepancies in contract terminology across jurisdictions, but reassures that it's often not a critical issue.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware of the specific legal definitions in their jurisdiction, even if 'novation' is commonly used.
content.source_insight: The text explains the common usage and interpretation of 'novation'.

content.verbatim_text: “Except as otherwise provided in this [Agreement], neither party may assign, novate, delegate, or transfer this [Agreement], or any of its individual rights or obligations under this [Agreement], without the prior written approval of the other Party, which approval will not be unreasonably withheld or delayed. Any attempted assignment, novation, delegation, or transfer without the necessary approval is void. However, [Zebracorp] may, without the prior written consent of the [Supplier], unconditionally assign, novate, delegate or transfer any or all of its rights and obligations under this [Agreement], in whole, in part, or through a splitting of the [Agreement], to any Affiliate or to any acquirer of a Zebracorp business line to which this contract relates. As of the effective date of the assignment, novation, delegation, or transfer, the assignee entity(ies) assumes all of the relevant rights, obligations and liabilities of the [Agreement], and [Zebracorp] is unconditionally released and discharged from all of the relevant rights, obligations and liabilities of the [Agreement]. [Supplier] will work cooperatively with [Zebracorp] and the assignee entity(ies) to ensure a smooth and orderly transition.”
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's preferred assignment clause states that neither party can assign, novate, delegate, or transfer the agreement (or its rights/obligations) without prior written approval, which won't be unreasonably withheld or delayed. Any unapproved attempt is void. However, Zebracorp can unconditionally assign, novate, delegate, or transfer any or all rights/obligations (wholly, partially, or by splitting) to an Affiliate or an acquirer of a relevant Zebracorp business line, without supplier consent. Upon transfer, the assignee assumes all relevant rights/obligations/liabilities, and Zebracorp is unconditionally released. The supplier must cooperate for a smooth transition.
content.expert_insight: This is Zebracorp's ideal assignment clause, embodying all its key requirements: general mutual consent (but not unreasonably withheld), explicit carve-outs for Zebracorp's internal restructuring (affiliates, business line sales) without consent, explicit release of Zebracorp from liability, and provisions for partial assignment/splitting. This clause is highly favorable to Zebracorp's operational and M&A flexibility.
content.conditions: This is Zebracorp's preferred language for assignment clauses in its contracts.
content.justification: To achieve maximum flexibility for Zebracorp's corporate restructuring and M&A activities, ensure a clean exit from liabilities, and maintain control over supplier assignments, as detailed in the preceding text.
content.implication_company: Secures Zebracorp's ability to restructure, divest, or acquire without needing supplier consent, and ensures it is fully released from liabilities post-assignment.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must grant consent (not unreasonably withheld) for Zebracorp's general assignments but cannot prevent assignments to Zebracorp affiliates or business line acquirers. They must also cooperate with the transition and accept Zebracorp's full release from liability.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly provides this as 'An example of our preferred assignment clause'.

content.verbatim_text: Assignment clauses can become critical in a sale of business, acquisition or other similar transaction. Having an obligation to obtain consents for assigning contracts from present contract parties can complicate and potentially sidetrack the contemplated transaction. Failure to pay close attention to the language of the assignment clause while the contract is being negotiated may also create an opportunity for the nontransferring party to later extort concessions in return to its consent to the contract assignment.
content.plain_text: Assignment clauses are crucial in business transactions like sales or acquisitions. Requiring consent for assignment can complicate or delay transactions, and overlooking the clause during negotiation can lead to extortionate demands later.
content.expert_insight: This emphasizes the strategic importance of assignment clauses beyond mere legal boilerplate. Proactive negotiation can prevent significant transactional hurdles and financial leverage being gained by counterparties during critical business events.
content.justification: Explains the significance and potential pitfalls of assignment clauses in business transactions.
content.implication_company: Poorly negotiated assignment clauses can lead to delays, increased costs, and potential extortion during M&A or reorganizations.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may gain leverage if Zebracorp needs their consent for assignment during a transaction.
content.source_insight: Highlights the business impact of assignment clauses.
content.text: Assignment clauses can become critical in a sale of business, acquisition or other similar transaction. content.verbatim_text: It is for these reasons important to make sure that each contract we conclude gives us the maximum flexibility to assign without the supplier’s consent to any succeeding entity to Zebracorp (in case of a reorganization), or at the minimum allow free assignment by Zebracorp to an affiliate (which accomplishes the same ability for re-organization if Zebracorp is acquired through a share purchase at the shareholder level).
content.plain_text: Zebracorp must ensure contracts allow maximum flexibility for assignment without supplier consent to any successor entity (reorganization) or, at minimum, free assignment to an affiliate (for share purchase acquisitions).
content.expert_insight: This is a core strategic objective for Zebracorp. Ensuring this flexibility upfront protects future corporate restructuring options and minimizes friction during M&A events. Prioritizing this avoids needing to renegotiate or seek numerous consents later.
content.conditions: Contract negotiation for new or renewing agreements.
content.justification: To avoid complications, delays, and potential extortion during reorganizations, sales of business, or acquisitions.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp maintains flexibility in corporate restructuring and M&A activities, reducing legal and transactional overhead.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier may lose control over who Zebracorp's counterparty becomes in certain scenarios, particularly during Zebracorp's internal reorganizations or acquisitions at the shareholder level.
content.source_insight: States Zebracorp's primary objective for assignment clauses.
content.text: It is for these reasons important to make sure that each contract we conclude gives us the maximum flexibility to assign without the supplier’s consent to any succeeding entity to Zebracorp (in case of a reorganization), or at the minimum allow free assignment by Zebracorp to an affiliate (which accomplishes the same ability for re-organization if Zebracorp is acquired through a share purchase at the shareholder level).

content.verbatim_text: In the event the supplier/subcontractor refuses to grant us right to assign to an affiliate, then we should at the very minimum have a note saying that the approval for the assignment will not be “arbitrarily or unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed”.
content.plain_text: If a supplier refuses to allow assignment to an affiliate, Zebracorp should ensure the contract specifies that any required approval for assignment will not be arbitrarily or unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed.
content.expert_insight: This provides a crucial fallback position. While not as ideal as free assignment, a 'not unreasonably withheld' standard offers legal recourse and prevents a supplier from using consent as a tool for leverage or obstruction without legitimate reason.
content.conditions: Supplier refuses to grant Zebracorp the right to freely assign to an affiliate.
content.justification: To prevent arbitrary or unreasonable obstruction of assignment by the supplier.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp gains some protection against arbitrary refusal, maintaining a degree of flexibility and reducing the risk of being held hostage by a supplier's unreasonable demands.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier's discretion to refuse assignment is limited by a reasonableness standard, requiring a legitimate business reason for refusal.
content.source_insight: Provides a minimum acceptable fallback position for assignment rights.
content.text: In the event the supplier/subcontractor refuses to grant us right to assign to an affiliate, then we should at the very minimum have a note saying that the approval for the assignment will not be “arbitrarily or unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed”.

content.verbatim_text: Our right to assign each contract should include also partial assignment of the contract. In many cases such partial assignment right is implicit from the right to assign the entire agreement, but it would be recommended to expressly agree on a right to assign the agreement either in its entirety or partially.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's assignment rights should explicitly include partial assignment, even if it's often implicit, to ensure clarity.
content.expert_insight: Explicitly stating partial assignment rights removes ambiguity and potential disputes. This is particularly valuable in complex transactions where only specific parts of a contract or business line might be transferred.
content.conditions: Contract negotiation.
content.justification: To ensure clarity and avoid potential disputes over the scope of assignment rights.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp has clear contractual ability to assign parts of a contract, providing greater flexibility in asset sales or divestitures.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier must acknowledge and potentially manage partial assignments, which could introduce administrative complexity.
content.source_insight: Recommends explicit inclusion of partial assignment rights.
content.text: Our right to assign each contract should include also partial assignment of the contract. In many cases such partial assignment right is implicit from the right to assign the entire agreement, but it would be recommended to expressly agree on a right to assign the agreement either in its entirety or partially.

content.verbatim_text: Ideally we should also seek to secure a right to ‘split’ the respective contract, in case of divestment of a Zebracorp business line so that both Zebracorp and any third party acquirer of any specific Zebracorp business line will continue to be able to use the same contract.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should aim to secure the right to 'split' contracts during business line divestments, allowing both Zebracorp and the acquirer to continue using the contract.
content.expert_insight: The ability to 'split' a contract is a sophisticated and highly beneficial provision for divestitures. It allows for seamless continuity of services or licenses for both the divesting and acquiring entities, preserving value and avoiding the need for new contract negotiations.
content.conditions: Divestment of a Zebracorp business line.
content.justification: To ensure continuity of contract usage for both Zebracorp and the acquirer in a divestment scenario.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp maintains operational continuity for divested business lines and facilitates smoother, more value-preserving sales of business units.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier may have to manage the same contract with two different entities post-split, potentially increasing administrative burden.
content.source_insight: Recommends securing the right to split contracts for divestments.
content.text: Ideally we should also seek to secure a right to ‘split’ the respective contract, in case of divestment of a Zebracorp business line so that both Zebracorp and any third party acquirer of any specific Zebracorp business line will continue to be able to use the same contract.

content.verbatim_text: Please note that, when negotiating the assignment clause with our suppliers/subcontractors, we would not wish to agree to a mutual assignment right. This means that in most cases we would rather forego our right to assign than to agree on any language that would allow the supplier/subcontractor to freely assign the agreement to a third party without our consent. This is because each of our suppliers have gone through a selection process where each supplier has been deemed financially and otherwise able to meet their eventual contractual commitments towards Zebracorp. Allowing the supplier to freely substitute itself to another third party would negate the entire selection process, and in worst case enable the supplier to effectively walk away from critical contractual commitments.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should not agree to mutual assignment rights with suppliers. It prefers to forgo its own assignment rights rather than allow suppliers to freely assign contracts without Zebracorp's consent.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical defensive position. Zebracorp's supplier selection process is a significant investment. Allowing free supplier assignment undermines this due diligence, exposing Zebracorp to unknown risks regarding performance, financial stability, and compliance. The asymmetry reflects the customer's need for control over its supply chain.
content.conditions: Negotiating assignment clauses with suppliers/subcontractors.
content.justification: Zebracorp's suppliers are selected based on their ability to meet commitments; free assignment by suppliers would negate this selection process and could allow them to avoid obligations or introduce unsuitable parties.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp maintains control over the identity and capabilities of its suppliers, protecting its supply chain and operational integrity.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier's ability to assign its contractual obligations is restricted, requiring Zebracorp's consent.
content.source_insight: Outlines Zebracorp's firm stance against mutual assignment rights with suppliers.
content.text: Please note that, when negotiating the assignment clause with our suppliers/subcontractors, we would not wish to agree to a mutual assignment right. This means that in most cases we would rather forego our right to assign than to agree on any language that would allow the supplier/subcontractor to freely assign the agreement to a third party without our consent. This is because each of our suppliers have gone through a selection process where each supplier has been deemed financially and otherwise able to meet their eventual contractual commitments towards Zebracorp. Allowing the supplier to freely substitute itself to another third party would negate the entire selection process, and in worst case enable the supplier to effectively walk away from critical contractual commitments.

content.verbatim_text: Also note that our right to assign the contract should not be made subject to us remaining jointly liable for the assigned contract together with the assignee. The assignment should be unconditional in the sense that Zebracorp will not accept liability for any commitments made by any third party assignee. The assignment should also provide a clean exit for Zebracorp in the sense that Zebracorp will not remain jointly liable under the assigned agreement with the new contracting party.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's right to assign contracts must not include remaining jointly liable with the assignee. The assignment should be unconditional, providing a clean exit for Zebracorp from all liabilities.
content.expert_insight: This is paramount for risk management. Retaining joint liability after assignment defeats a primary purpose of assignment – to transfer risk and responsibility. Ensuring a 'clean exit' protects Zebracorp from post-transaction liabilities and contingent claims.
content.conditions: Negotiating assignment clauses.
content.justification: To ensure a complete transfer of liability and provide Zebracorp with a clean exit from contractual obligations post-assignment.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp avoids ongoing liability for contracts it has assigned, ensuring a clean break and reducing future risk exposure.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier must look solely to the assignee for performance and liability post-assignment, as Zebracorp will not remain jointly liable.
content.source_insight: Emphasizes the need for unconditional assignment without residual liability for Zebracorp.
content.text: Also note that our right to assign the contract should not be made subject to us remaining jointly liable for the assigned contract together with the assignee. The assignment should be unconditional in the sense that Zebracorp will not accept liability for any commitments made by any third party assignee. The assignment should also provide a clean exit for Zebracorp in the sense that Zebracorp will not remain jointly liable under the assigned agreement with the new contracting party.

content.verbatim_text: When planning acquisitions or such other corporate transactions, the acquiring party will usually have to consider how it prefers to structure the transactions. The acquiring party can either elect to purchase the target company's assets (which enables the acquiring party to pick and choose only the assets and contracts they desire) or alternatively it may elect to acquire the entire company. In an asset sale, the need for contract-by-contract due diligence, would become particularly important since each contract needs to be specifically assigned in the context of asset sale. The acquiring party would generally be able to avoid such issues by electing to acquire the entire share capital of the target company (thereby making it a subsidiary of the acquiring entity) or by merging together with the target company. In the latter case (i.e. when the acquiring party obtains all outstanding shares in the target company and makes the acquired company its subsidiary), there is strictly speaking no need to obtain a consent for the assignment of the related contracts. This is because the contracts in themselves are not ‘assigned’ to any new legal entity but only the owner of the existing legal entity changes. Contrary to widely held belief, changes in ownership do not generally require the other contracting party’s consent. In companies whose shares are stock-listed the ownership changes each day the market is open.
content.plain_text: This section explains how corporate transactions (asset sale vs. share acquisition/merger) impact contract assignment. In an asset sale, individual contracts must be assigned. In a share acquisition or merger, contracts generally remain with the existing legal entity, and changes in ownership typically do not require third-party consent, avoiding assignment issues.
content.expert_insight: This provides essential context for M&A strategy. Understanding the distinction between asset and share deals, and how 'change of ownership' differs from 'assignment' in legal terms, is crucial for efficient transaction planning and avoiding unnecessary consent processes.
content.justification: Explains the legal implications of different M&A structures on contract assignment.
content.implication_company: In a share acquisition or merger, Zebracorp can often avoid the need for individual contract assignments, streamlining the transaction process.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers generally cannot object to a change of ownership of Zebracorp unless specifically contractually agreed.
content.source_insight: Provides background on different M&A structures and their implications for contract assignment.
content.text: When planning acquisitions or such other corporate transactions, the acquiring party will usually have to consider how it prefers to structure the transactions. The acquiring party can either elect to purchase the target company's assets (which enables the acquiring party to pick and choose only the assets and contracts they desire) or alternatively it may elect to acquire the entire company. In an asset sale, the need for contract-by-contract due diligence, would become particularly important since each contract needs to be specifically assigned in the context of asset sale. The acquiring party would generally be able to avoid such issues by electing to acquire the entire share capital of the target company (thereby making it a subsidiary of the acquiring entity) or by merging together with the target company. In the latter case (i.e. when the acquiring party obtains all outstanding shares in the target company and makes the acquired company its subsidiary), there is strictly speaking no need to obtain a consent for the assignment of the related contracts. This is because the contracts in themselves are not ‘assigned’ to any new legal entity but only the owner of the existing legal entity changes. Contrary to widely held belief, changes in ownership do not generally require the other contracting party’s consent. In companies whose shares are stock-listed the ownership changes each day the market is open.

content.verbatim_text: An acquisition or a merger would in most countries serve to "vest" all assets and liabilities including contracts automatically to a merging and surviving entity or the acquiring party, as the case may be, by ‘operation of law’ without a need to obtain a consent from the opposing party. The parties are of course free to agree between themselves that a ownership change of certain magnitude (in e.g. affecting over 50 % of all outstanding shares) will require the other party’s consent.
content.plain_text: In most countries, acquisitions or mergers automatically transfer assets and liabilities, including contracts, by "operation of law," without requiring consent from the other party. However, parties can contractually agree that significant ownership changes require consent.
content.expert_insight: This clarifies the default legal position regarding 'operation of law' transfers. While generally beneficial for M&A, it's critical to be aware that specific contractual clauses can override this default, necessitating careful review of change of control provisions.
content.justification: Explains the legal principle of 'operation of law' in M&A contexts.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can generally rely on automatic transfer of contracts by operation of law in M&A, unless specific contractual clauses dictate otherwise.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier contracts may be transferred by operation of law without their consent, unless a specific change of control clause is in place.
content.source_insight: Explains the concept of 'assignment by operation of law' and its default application in M&A.
content.text: An acquisition or a merger would in most countries serve to "vest" all assets and liabilities including contracts automatically to a merging and surviving entity or the acquiring party, as the case may be, by ‘operation of law’ without a need to obtain a consent from the opposing party. The parties are of course free to agree between themselves that a ownership change of certain magnitude (in e.g. affecting over 50 % of all outstanding shares) will require the other party’s consent.

content.verbatim_text: Also, clauses that prohibit any transfer by any kind of merger or "change of control" are not uncommon. Below is an example of such clause: “Any attempted assignment of this [Agreement] whether directly, by change in control or by operation of law, shall be ineffective unless effected with the other party’s prior written consent”. Variants of the above provision can be found in particular in suppliers’ own contract templates.
content.plain_text: It is common to find clauses that prohibit transfers by merger or "change of control." An example clause states that any attempted assignment, including by change of control or operation of law, is ineffective without prior written consent.
content.expert_insight: This example is a warning sign. These 'anti-assignment by operation of law' or 'change of control' clauses are highly restrictive and can severely impede M&A activities. Identifying and negotiating these out is crucial for Zebracorp's strategic flexibility.
content.justification: Provides a concrete example of a common restrictive clause.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must be vigilant for such clauses in supplier contracts as they can complicate or prevent M&A transactions.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers often include these clauses to maintain control over who their counterparty is, even in cases of corporate restructuring.
content.source_insight: Illustrates a common restrictive clause encountered in contracts, especially from suppliers.
content.text: Also, clauses that prohibit any transfer by any kind of merger or "change of control" are not uncommon. Below is an example of such clause: “Any attempted assignment of this [Agreement] whether directly, by change in control or by operation of law, shall be ineffective unless effected with the other party’s prior written consent”. Variants of the above provision can be found in particular in suppliers’ own contract templates.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp’s firm view is that assignment of contract by operation of law should not require the supplier’s consent, and in most cases we should reject any language that requires us to seek consent from other party in connection with transfer of agreement by operation of law. This is largely due to the fact that these type of provisions are likely to cause complications when planning mergers, acquisitions or such other transactions. For example, if Zebracorp was planning on forming a merger with another company, we would work from the assumption that our contracts with our suppliers/subcontractors would be automatically transferred to the new merged entity by operation of law without the need seek consents from our supplier base. An assignment restriction described above is likely to impact the timing, cost and our ability to consummate a "smooth" merger or such other transaction.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's position is that assignment by operation of law should not require supplier consent, and it should reject clauses mandating such consent, as these complicate M&A transactions.
content.expert_insight: This is a non-negotiable stance for Zebracorp. Clauses requiring consent for transfers by operation of law are direct impediments to efficient M&A. Rejecting them is essential for maintaining strategic agility and minimizing transactional friction.
content.conditions: Negotiating assignment clauses, particularly those related to changes of control or operation of law.
content.justification: Such provisions hinder smooth mergers and acquisitions by impacting timing, cost, and feasibility, requiring numerous consents from the supplier base.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp aims to maintain flexibility and efficiency in corporate restructuring without needing to seek numerous supplier consents, thereby reducing M&A execution risk.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier loses the right to consent to transfers of contracts resulting from Zebracorp's M&A activities, which are typically outside the supplier's direct control.
content.source_insight: States Zebracorp's firm view on assignment by operation of law and its rationale.
content.text: Zebracorp’s firm view is that assignment of contract by operation of law should not require the supplier’s consent, and in most cases we should reject any language that requires us to seek consent from other party in connection with transfer of agreement by operation of law. This is largely due to the fact that these type of provisions are likely to cause complications when planning mergers, acquisitions or such other transactions. For example, if Zebracorp was planning on forming a merger with another company, we would work from the assumption that our contracts with our suppliers/subcontractors would be automatically transferred to the new merged entity by operation of law without the need seek consents from our supplier base. An assignment restriction described above is likely to impact the timing, cost and our ability to consummate a "smooth" merger or such other transaction.

content.verbatim_text: In those critical R&D contracts and the like where we do impose these very same assignment restrictions on our suppliers, it would be better to abandon the entire clause than to agree to mutual clause that would restrict Zebracorp from assigning the contract. The fact that Zebracorp is not willing to make these assignment provisions mutual can often be explained to the supplier by the asymmetric contractual relationship i.e. that of the customer and the supplier. In most cases, we can make the contract more palatable to the supplier by agreeing to allow the supplier transfer the contract by operation of law to any party that is not a direct competitor of Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: In critical R&D contracts where Zebracorp restricts supplier assignment, it's better to remove the clause entirely than to make it mutual and restrict Zebracorp. This non-mutuality can be justified by the customer-supplier relationship. To make it more acceptable, Zebracorp can allow suppliers to transfer by operation of law to non-competitors.
content.expert_insight: This highlights a pragmatic approach to balancing Zebracorp's own strategic needs with supplier relations. Sacrificing a restrictive clause on suppliers is sometimes acceptable if the alternative is self-imposed restriction. The 'non-competitor' carve-out is a smart concession to make the non-mutual clause more palatable.
content.conditions: Critical R&D contracts where Zebracorp imposes assignment restrictions on suppliers.
content.justification: Prioritizing Zebracorp's own assignment flexibility over restricting supplier assignments in specific cases, and leveraging the asymmetric customer-supplier relationship for negotiation.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp prioritizes its own assignment flexibility, even if it means sacrificing some control over supplier assignments in specific contexts. It gains a negotiation tactic to soothe supplier concerns.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may gain some flexibility in assignment by operation of law, provided the assignee is not a direct competitor of Zebracorp, making the non-mutual clause more acceptable.
content.source_insight: Provides guidance on managing assignment restrictions in critical contracts and negotiation tactics.
content.text: In those critical R&D contracts and the like where we do impose these very same assignment restrictions on our suppliers, it would be better to abandon the entire clause than to agree to mutual clause that would restrict Zebracorp from assigning the contract. The fact that Zebracorp is not willing to make these assignment provisions mutual can often be explained to the supplier by the asymmetric contractual relationship i.e. that of the customer and the supplier. In most cases, we can make the contract more palatable to the supplier by agreeing to allow the supplier transfer the contract by operation of law to any party that is not a direct competitor of Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: Under UK laws, an assignment of rights under a contract is normally restricted solely to the benefits of the contract. Where a party wishes to transfer both the benefit and burden of the contract without any residual liability (as is usually the case), the assignment of the contract would generally needs to be done by way of a novation. For this reason, when the agreement is governed by UK laws, it is useful to specifically mention that the agreement is not only assigned but also novated, and the transfer of the rights and obligations may require the execution of a specific novation agreement. Please speak to a member of the Legal & Compliance team to obtain the appropriate templates/language. Due to the prevalence of UK origin contract documentation, the term novation and novation agreements in general are often (incorrectly) used in other jurisdictions as well when the parties should be talking about contract transfer or assignment. This in itself is not issue in the majority of cases, as most jurisdictions will recognize the term novation to mean the same as transfer of a contract.
content.plain_text: Under UK law, assignment typically transfers only benefits, while novation is needed to transfer both benefits and burdens without residual liability. For UK-governed contracts, explicitly state "assigned and novated" and consult Legal for templates. The term "novation" is often used broadly, but most jurisdictions recognize it as contract transfer.
content.expert_insight: This is crucial for contracts governed by UK law. Misunderstanding the distinction between assignment and novation can lead to unintended retained liabilities. Always seek legal counsel for UK-governed agreements to ensure proper transfer of both rights and obligations.
content.justification: Explains the legal distinction between assignment and novation, particularly under UK law.
content.implication_company: For UK-governed contracts, Zebracorp must ensure novation is properly executed to fully transfer both benefits and burdens and avoid residual liability.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers dealing with UK-governed contracts need to understand the implications of novation for their contractual relationships.
content.source_insight: Provides legal context on assignment vs. novation, particularly under UK law, and advises on terminology.

Where a party wishes to transfer both the benefit and burden of the contract without any residual liability (as is usually the case), the assignment of the contract would generally needs to be done by way of a novation. For this reason, when the agreement is governed by UK laws, it is useful to specifically mention that the agreement is not only assigned but also novated, and the transfer of the rights and obligations may require the execution of a specific novation agreement. Please speak to a member of the Legal & Compliance team to obtain the appropriate templates/language. Due to the prevalence of UK origin contract documentation, the term novation and novation agreements in general are often (incorrectly) used in other jurisdictions as well when the parties should be talking about contract transfer or assignment. This in itself is not issue in the majority of cases, as most jurisdictions will recognize the term novation to mean the same as transfer of a contract.

content.verbatim_text: Companies have the freedom to change the trade name that they use to conduct their business. When changing the name of the company, the registered legal entity which can be identified through each company’s individual registration number remains the same. These type of changes in the name or registered addresses of a company are not regarded as assignments so long as the underlying legal entity remains the same and only the name/address of the company changes. Accordingly, there is no need to seek or grant consent to such change of name/registered address alone. A unilateral notification of the name change to the other contracting party should be sufficient. While it is recommended to clarify the name change in future contract amendments, strictly speaking this is not necessary. The name change can be mentioned in a contract amendment in e.g. by adding a following note in brackets after the name of the contracting party: e.g. “(formerly known as Zebracorp Space)” or, in short, “(f/k/a Zebracorp Space)”
content.plain_text: Changes to a company's name or registered address are not considered assignments if the underlying legal entity remains the same. Therefore, no consent is required, only a unilateral notification. While clarifying in future contract amendments is recommended, it's not strictly necessary.
content.expert_insight: This is an important clarification that simplifies administrative processes. Differentiating a mere name change from a legal entity change (which could trigger assignment clauses) prevents unnecessary consent requests and potential delays.
content.justification: Clarifies that company name/address changes do not constitute assignments if the legal entity remains the same.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can change its name or address without needing to obtain consent from contract parties, simplifying administrative processes.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier does not have a right to consent to Zebracorp's name or address changes, only to be notified.
content.source_insight: Explains the distinction between company name changes and assignments.
content.text: Companies have the freedom to change the trade name that they use to conduct their business. When changing the name of the company, the registered legal entity which can be identified through each company’s individual registration number remains the same. These type of changes in the name or registered addresses of a company are not regarded as assignments so long as the underlying legal entity remains the same and only the name/address of the company changes. Accordingly, there is no need to seek or grant consent to such change of name/registered address alone. While it is recommended to clarify the name change in future contract amendments, strictly speaking this is not necessary. The name change can be mentioned in a contract amendment in e.g. by adding a following note in brackets after the name of the contracting party: e.g. “(formerly known as Zebracorp Space)” or, in short, “(f/k/a Zebracorp Space)”

content.verbatim_text: “Except as otherwise provided in this [Agreement], neither party may assign, novate, delegate, or transfer this [Agreement], or any of its individual rights or obligations under this [Agreement], without the prior written approval of the other Party, which approval will not be unreasonably withheld or delayed. Any attempted assignment, novation, delegation, or transfer without the necessary approval is void. However, [Zebracorp] may, without the prior written consent of the [Supplier], unconditionally assign, novate, delegate or transfer any or all of its rights and obligations under this [Agreement], in whole, in part, or through a splitting of the [Agreement], to any Affiliate or to any acquirer of a Zebracorp business line to which this contract relates. As of the effective date of the assignment, novation, delegation, or transfer, the assignee entity(ies) assumes all of the relevant rights, obligations and liabilities of the [Agreement], and [Zebracorp] is unconditionally released and discharged from all of the relevant rights, obligations and liabilities of the [Agreement]. [Supplier] will work cooperatively with [Zebracorp] and the assignee entity(ies) to ensure a smooth and orderly transition.”
content.plain_text: This is Zebracorp's preferred assignment clause. It generally requires mutual consent for assignment (not to be unreasonably withheld), but grants Zebracorp the unconditional right to assign, novate, delegate, or transfer all or part of its rights and obligations, including splitting the agreement, to an affiliate or an acquirer of a business line without supplier consent. Upon such transfer, Zebracorp is fully released from liabilities, and the supplier must cooperate for a smooth transition.
content.expert_insight: This clause effectively encapsulates all of Zebracorp's preferred positions: general mutual consent with a 'not unreasonably withheld' standard, but critical unilateral rights for Zebracorp for internal reorganizations, affiliates, and divestitures, coupled with a clean release of liability. This is a robust, company-centric assignment provision.
content.justification: Provides a concrete example of Zebracorp's desired contractual language for assignment.
content.implication_company: This clause ensures maximum flexibility for Zebracorp in corporate restructuring and M&A, including divestitures, with a clean exit from liabilities.
content.implication_supplier: Supplier's ability to assign is restricted by Zebracorp's consent, while Zebracorp has broad unilateral assignment rights in specific scenarios, and the supplier must cooperate with any such assignment.
content.source_insight: Provides a concrete example of Zebracorp's desired contractual language for assignment, embodying the principles discussed earlier.
content.text: “Except as otherwise provided in this [Agreement], neither party may assign, novate, delegate, or transfer this [Agreement], or any of its individual rights or obligations under this [Agreement], without the prior written approval of the other Party, which approval will not be unreasonably withheld or delayed. Any attempted assignment, novation, delegation, or transfer without the necessary approval is void. However, [Zebracorp] may, without the prior written consent of the [Supplier], unconditionally assign, novate, delegate or transfer any or all of its rights and obligations under this [Agreement], in whole, in part, or through a splitting of the [Agreement], to any Affiliate or to any acquirer of a Zebracorp business line to which this contract relates. As of the effective date of the assignment, novation, delegation, or transfer, the assignee entity(ies) assumes all of the relevant rights, obligations and liabilities of the [Agreement], and [Zebracorp] is unconditionally released and discharged from all of the relevant rights, obligations and liabilities of the [Agreement]. [Supplier] will work cooperatively with [Zebracorp] and the assignee entity(ies) to ensure a smooth and orderly transition.”
